natural problem: The Screamers are coached by Coach Yellsalot.  The Screamers have 12 players, but two of them, Bob and Yogi, refuse to play together.  How many starting lineups (of 5 players) can Coach Yellsalot make, if the starting lineup can't contain both Bob and Yogi?  (The order of the 5 players in the lineup does not matter; that is, two lineups are the same if they consist of the same 5 players.)
natural solution: There are 3 different cases for the starting lineup. Case 1: Bob starts (and Yogi doesn't). In this case, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players (remember that Yogi won't play, so there are only 10 players left to select from).
Thus there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups that the coach can choose. Case 2: Yogi starts (and Bob doesn't). As in Case 1, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players.
So there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups in this case. Case 3: Neither Bob nor Yogi starts. In this case, the coach must choose all 5 players in the lineup from the 10 remaining players.
Hence there are $\binom{10}{5}$ lineups in this case.
To get the total number of starting lineups, we add the number of lineups in each of the cases: $$ \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{5} = 210 + 210 + 252 = \boxed{672}. $$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes lineups :: nat
assumes h0 : "lineups = (nchoosek 10 5 - nchoosek 8 3)"
shows  "lineups = 672"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Screamers are coached by Coach Yellsalot.  The Screamers have 12 players, but two of them, Bob and Yogi, refuse to play together.  How many starting lineups (of 5 players) can Coach Yellsalot make, if the starting lineup can't contain both Bob and Yogi?  (The order of the 5 players in the lineup does not matter; that is, two lineups are the same if they consist of the same 5 players.) The final Answer is 672
 ### Proof
 There are 3 different cases for the starting lineup. Case 1: Bob starts (and Yogi doesn't). In this case, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players (remember that Yogi won't play, so there are only 10 players left to select from).
 Thus there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups that the coach can choose. Case 2: Yogi starts (and Bob doesn't). As in Case 1, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players.
 So there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups in this case. Case 3: Neither Bob nor Yogi starts. In this case, the coach must choose all 5 players in the lineup from the 10 remaining players.
 Hence there are $\binom{10}{5}$ lineups in this case.
 To get the total number of starting lineups, we add the number of lineups in each of the cases: $$ \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{5} = 210 + 210 + 252 = \boxed{672}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes lineups :: nat
assumes h0 : "lineups = (nchoosek 10 5 - nchoosek 8 3)"
shows  "lineups = 672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many ways can you form a lineup of 5 people out of 10, excluding the cases where 3 specific people are chosen together? The final answer is 672.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. nCr n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h1 : "fact 10 = 3628800"
and h2 : "fact 4 = 24"
and h3 : "fact 6 = 720"
and h4 : "fact 5 = 120"
shows  "nCr 10 5 - nCr 9 4 = 672"

fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

and h3 : "fact 6 = 720"
and h4 : "fact 5 = 120"
shows  "nCr 10 5 - nCr 9 4 = 672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In how many ways can you choose 5 items out of 10? And how many ways can you choose 4 items out of 9? Find the difference between these two numbers. The final answer is 672.

a_2.formal problem:

assumes h0 : "numberOfLineups = (
                 (n_choose_k 10 5) + 
                 (n_choose_k 10 4) * 2)"
and h1 : "n_choose_k n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "numberOfLineups = 672"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "\<forall>n k. C n k = (fact n) div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h3 : "C 12 5 = 792"
shows  "(C (n - 1) k + C (n - 1) (k - 1)) = 672"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Screamers are coached by Coach Yellsalot.  The Screamers have 12 players, but two of them, Bob and Yogi, refuse to play together.  How many starting lineups (of 5 players) can Coach Yellsalot make, if the starting lineup can't contain both Bob and Yogi?  (The order of the 5 players in the lineup does not matter; that is, two lineups are the same if they consist of the same 5 players.) The final Answer is 672
 ### Proof
 There are 3 different cases for the starting lineup. Case 1: Bob starts (and Yogi doesn't). In this case, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players (remember that Yogi won't play, so there are only 10 players left to select from).
 Thus there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups that the coach can choose. Case 2: Yogi starts (and Bob doesn't). As in Case 1, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players.
 So there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups in this case. Case 3: Neither Bob nor Yogi starts. In this case, the coach must choose all 5 players in the lineup from the 10 remaining players.
 Hence there are $\binom{10}{5}$ lineups in this case.
 To get the total number of starting lineups, we add the number of lineups in each of the cases: $$ \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{5} = 210 + 210 + 252 = \boxed{672}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat and C :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "k = 5"
and h2 : "\<forall>n k. C n k = (fact n) div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
and h3 : "C 12 5 = 792"
shows  "(C (n - 1) k + C (n - 1) (k - 1)) = 672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a set of 12 items, the number of ways to choose 5 items is 792. If one item is removed from the set, what is the sum of the number of ways to choose 5 items and the number of ways to choose 4 items from the remaining 11 items? The final answer is 672.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_players num_lineups :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_players = 12"
and h1 : "num_lineups = (nCr (num_players - 1) 4 - nCr (num_players - 2) 3)"
and h2 : "nCr n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "num_lineups = 672"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Screamers are coached by Coach Yellsalot.  The Screamers have 12 players, but two of them, Bob and Yogi, refuse to play together.  So there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups in this case. Case 3: Neither Bob nor Yogi starts. In this case, the coach must choose all 5 players in the lineup from the 10 remaining players.

fixes num_players num_lineups :: nat

and h1 : "num_lineups = (nCr (num_players - 1) 4 - nCr (num_players - 2) 3)"
and h2 : "nCr n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "num_lineups = 672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: There are 12 players on a basketball team, and the coach wants to select a lineup of 5 players. How many different lineups can be formed if the coach can choose any 5 players out of the 12, except for two players who never play together? The final answer is 672.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes starting_lineups :: nat and nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n r. nCr n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "starting_lineups = nCr 10 5 + nCr 10 4"
shows  "starting_lineups = 672"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Screamers are coached by Coach Yellsalot.  The Screamers have 12 players, but two of them, Bob and Yogi, refuse to play together.  How many starting lineups (of 5 players) can Coach Yellsalot make, if the starting lineup can't contain both Bob and Yogi?  (The order of the 5 players in the lineup does not matter; that is, two lineups are the same if they consist of the same 5 players.) The final Answer is 672
 ### Proof
 There are 3 different cases for the starting lineup. Case 1: Bob starts (and Yogi doesn't). In this case, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players (remember that Yogi won't play, so there are only 10 players left to select from).
 Thus there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups that the coach can choose. Case 2: Yogi starts (and Bob doesn't). As in Case 1, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players.
 So there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups in this case. Case 3: Neither Bob nor Yogi starts. In this case, the coach must choose all 5 players in the lineup from the 10 remaining players.
 Hence there are $\binom{10}{5}$ lineups in this case.
 To get the total number of starting lineups, we add the number of lineups in each of the cases: $$ \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{5} = 210 + 210 + 252 = \boxed{672}. $$
 *)

theorem 
fixes starting_lineups :: nat and nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n r. nCr n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
and h1 : "starting_lineups = nCr 10 5 + nCr 10 4"
shows  "starting_lineups = 672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many starting lineups can be formed by choosing 5 or 4 players from a team of 10? The final answer is 672.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes starting_lineups :: nat and players :: nat
assumes h0 : "players = 12"
and h1 : "\<forall>lineups. card lineups = 5 \<and> (\<forall>x y. x \<in> lineups \<and> y \<in> lineups \<longrightarrow> x \<noteq> y) \<longrightarrow>
  ((\<exists>Bob Yogi. Bob \<in> lineups \<and> Yogi \<in> lineups \<and> (\<forall>z. z \<in> lineups \<longrightarrow> z = Bob \<or> z = Yogi)) \<longrightarrow>
    (\<forall>lineups'. card lineups' = 5 \<and> (\<forall>x' y'. x' \<in> lineups' \<and> y' \<in> lineups' \<longrightarrow> x' \<noteq> y') \<longrightarrow>
      (\<exists>Bob' Yogi'. Bob' \<in> lineups' \<and> Yogi' \<in> lineups' \<and> (\<forall>z'. z' \<in> lineups' \<longrightarrow> z' = Bob' \<or> z' = Yogi'))))"
shows  "starting_lineups = 672"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Screamers are coached by Coach Yellsalot.  The Screamers have 12 players, but two of them, Bob and Yogi, refuse to play together.  How many starting lineups (of 5 players) can Coach Yellsalot make, if the starting lineup can't contain both Bob and Yogi?  (The order of the 5 players in the lineup does not matter; that is, two lineups are the same if they consist of the same 5 players.) The final Answer is 672
 ### Proof
 There are 3 different cases for the starting lineup. Case 1: Bob starts (and Yogi doesn't). In this case, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players (remember that Yogi won't play, so there are only 10 players left to select from).
 Thus there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups that the coach can choose. Case 2: Yogi starts (and Bob doesn't). As in Case 1, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players.
 So there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups in this case. Case 3: Neither Bob nor Yogi starts. In this case, the coach must choose all 5 players in the lineup from the 10 remaining players.
 Hence there are $\binom{10}{5}$ lineups in this case.
 To get the total number of starting lineups, we add the number of lineups in each of the cases: $$ \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{5} = 210 + 210 + 252 = \boxed{672}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes starting_lineups :: nat and players :: nat
assumes h0 : "players = 12"
and h1 : "\<forall>lineups. card lineups = 5 \<and> (\<forall>x y. x \<in> lineups \<and> y \<in> lineups \<longrightarrow> x \<noteq> y) \<longrightarrow>
  ((\<exists>Bob Yogi. Bob \<in> lineups \<and> Yogi \<in> lineups \<and> (\<forall>z. z \<in> lineups \<longrightarrow> z = Bob \<or> z = Yogi)) \<longrightarrow>
    (\<forall>lineups'. card lineups' = 5 \<and> (\<forall>x' y'. x' \<in> lineups' \<and> y' \<in> lineups' \<longrightarrow> x' \<noteq> y') \<longrightarrow>
      (\<exists>Bob' Yogi'. Bob' \<in> lineups' \<and> Yogi' \<in> lineups' \<and> (\<forall>z'. z' \<in> lineups' \<longrightarrow> z' = Bob' \<or> z' = Yogi'))))"
shows  "starting_lineups = 672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A basketball team has 12 players. Among them, there are two players, Bob and Yogi, who are always in the starting lineup together. In how many different ways can the coach choose a 5-player starting lineup? The final answer is 672.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes starting_lineups :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card starting_lineups = nchoosek (12 - 2) 5 + nchoosek (12 - 1) 4"
shows  "card starting_lineups = 672"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Screamers are coached by Coach Yellsalot.  The Screamers have 12 players, but two of them, Bob and Yogi, refuse to play together.  How many starting lineups (of 5 players) can Coach Yellsalot make, if the starting lineup can't contain both Bob and Yogi?  (The order of the 5 players in the lineup does not matter; that is, two lineups are the same if they consist of the same 5 players.) The final Answer is 672
 ### Proof
 There are 3 different cases for the starting lineup. Case 1: Bob starts (and Yogi doesn't). In this case, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players (remember that Yogi won't play, so there are only 10 players left to select from).
 Thus there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups that the coach can choose. Case 2: Yogi starts (and Bob doesn't). As in Case 1, the coach must choose 4 more players from the 10 remaining players.
 So there are $\binom{10}{4}$ lineups in this case. Case 3: Neither Bob nor Yogi starts. In this case, the coach must choose all 5 players in the lineup from the 10 remaining players.
 Hence there are $\binom{10}{5}$ lineups in this case.
 To get the total number of starting lineups, we add the number of lineups in each of the cases: $$ \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{4} + \binom{10}{5} = 210 + 210 + 252 = \boxed{672}. $$
 *)

theorem
fixes starting_lineups :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card starting_lineups = nchoosek (12 - 2) 5 + nchoosek (12 - 1) 4"
shows  "card starting_lineups = 672"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a basketball team consisting of 12 players, how many different starting lineups of 5 players can be formed if 2 players cannot play together, and one specific player must always be included? The final answer is 672.
